div.p: Meetings of the select Committee on W. Cost Johnson’s plan for creating two hundred millions of dollars of 3 per Cent Stocks hypothecated on the proceeds of the sales of the public lands, to be distributed among the States to relieve them in the payment of their debts— Present Johnson, Gentry, Cravens, Howard, Cooper, and Adams.— We were to meet at 9. but it was half an hour later before we formed a Quorum, and as the house met at 10. we had no time for discussion, nor even for reading the chairman’s report which was itself not finished.— We agreed to take some opportunity, while the house were in Session, to slip out of the hall, and meet again in the Committee room again which we did— Mr. Johnson’s report was not yet finished—but he read what he had written, and it was agreed that he should finish it, and present it to the house to-morrow— It is to conclude with two Resolutions— 1. That It is expedient that the Government of the Union should come to the aid of the States to assist them in the payment of their debts, by the application of their common property in the public lands— And 2. That a Committee be appointed to prepare a Bill, for that purpose— But foreseeing that the first resolution, if a question be taken upon it in the house will certainly be rejected,—I offered three Resolutions as a substitute for it in the event of its rejection. 1. That repudiation by a State of a debt contracted with foreigners is a violation of the Constitution of the United States in the Article which prohibits every State from passing any Law impairing the obligation of contracts. 2. That if any State shall by such repudiation involve herself in War, Congress has no power to involve the Nation in that War. 3. That if any State should involve herself in such a War, she would cease to be a State of this Union, and would have no claim to the aid of the other States of the Union for her defence— No objection was made to my introducing these resolutions as a substitute; but they startled every member of the Committee present, and evidently disconcerted Johnson— He had blinked the question of repudiation and War, without the preliminary settlement of which his project is mere moonshine. At the house amidst the usual confusion always incident to the last three days of a Session of Congress, specially aggravated by the last agonies of a Congress itself, the day was almost wholly consumed in unprofitable debate on the amendments proposed by the Senate to the navy appropriation bill; the merits and demerits of Dr Barton as chief of the medical, and surgical bureau, under the new organization of the Navy Department, and whether the chief of an other bureau should be a captain or a purser in the Navy. All the amendments of the Senate were acted upon in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; Robert M’Lellan in the chair— Adjourned after 5. Evening visits from Mrs Seaton, with Mrs Hale, and her daughter— Also from Mr Leavitt who took leave, about to return to Boston.

Fahrenheit 14. Meeting of the Committee of foreign Affairs— Present Adams, Everett, Granger, Stuart, Meriwether— We had the documents relating to the Republic of Hayti, and those relating to the occupation of Monterey by Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones before us— They had been sent for to the printers, and not one of them had been printed—although the Hayti Message had been referred to the Committee, on the 31st. of December, and the papers had been at the printers ever since.— I offered a Resolution upon each of these sets of papers to be reported to the house. That a Consul ought to be forthwith appointed to the Republic of Hayti, to prosecute the claims of our citizens; and a strong declaratory Resolution against the invasion of the territory of a foreign State at peace with the United States, by any military or naval officer; but there being a bare quorum at the meeting, the questions were postponed in the expectation of a fuller meeting to-morrow— Mr Everett also proposed two Resolutions respecting the right of visitation at sea for consideration to-morrow. At the house Reynolds of Illinois presented several impertinent resolutions of the Legislature of that State— Illinois is one of the bilking States, and Reynolds is one of her accredited cheats; and these States just as they grow bold in spunging their debts, they become profuse of their advice to Congress— Edward D. White of Louisiana, in his peculiar and somewhat ludicrous style, complained of having been personally insulted, by reflections upon the imputed disaffection of the people of Louisiana, at the time of the english invasion in 1815— Those imputations he said were utterly false, and he wanted to prove it—(W. O. Butler had charged them in his speech.) White asked that the house should immediately after the morning hour go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union to take up Senate Bill N. 12 to refund General Jackson’s fine— This was a spurt and came to nothing.— Winthrop called up the Resolutions appended to his report from the Committee of Commerce, on the oppression of coloured Seamen in Southern ports. Cave Johnson moved to lay the subject on the table yeas and nays 86 to 59.— A desperate struggle was made to recharter for ten years the District Banks—defeated by Cave Johnson, Atherton and Weller. W. Cost Johnson presented his report and resolutions, on the two hundred millions of stocks project, which were ordered to be printed— A desperate effort was made favoured by Johnson himself, to exclude from reception my resolutions offered as a substitute for the first of his— They failed to exclude them from reception; but by yeas and nays, 72 to 108. they refused to print them— I defeated a Bill of W. O. Butler from the Committee of military Affairs, to restore the 2d regiment of dragoons and much Artillery.— The Code for the Navy—reduction of postage, and the navy appropriation bill absorbed the time of the house till 7 in the Evening when sundry motions to adjourn, and a call of the house were rejected, and the adjournment at last carried by yeas and nays 89 to 76.

Meeting of the Committee of foreign Affairs.— Present Adams, Cushing, Everett, Granger, Shepperd, Caruthers, Meriwether— Absent Stuart and Holmes— Cushing was asked if he was ready to report upon the case of the Florida territorial bonds; and answered that he was not— Precisely so he did at the close of the last Session— Upon my Resolution that a Consul to the republic of Hayti, ought to be appointed the vote to lay it on the table was unanimous except my own— Everett, and Granger as well as Cushing voting in submission to the South— But my Resolution against the invasion of foreign territories by any naval or military Officer in time of Peace was voted for by every member present, except Caleb Cushing, who voted against it— Mr Everett offered his two resolutions concerning the right of visitation at sea; but they were laid on the table by the vote of all the members present except Everett and me— I asked Cushing if he was acting as an Executive Officer or as a member of the house— He smiled and answered in good humour that he did not know. The Committee adjourned without day— In the house, the chaos of a closing Congress was more than usually magnificent— The 16th joint rule of the two houses enjoining that no new bill shall be sent from one house to the other on the last three days of a Session, and the 17th. that no bill shall be sent to the President for his signature on the last day of a Session were suspended first for particular bills, and then without limitation.— Committees of conference on the civil and diplomatic and the Navy Appropriation Bills and some others were appointed, and adjusted sundry differences of details— Christopher H. Williams by dint of importunity got the house into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon a bill to divide the Country into two military divisions for the benefit of General Gaines, but the bill failed— Atherton was in the chair— The house took a recess from 4 to 6. O’Clock—and when the time for resuming the Session came Atherton and his gang attempted to transact business with less than half a Quorum—while Gwin was leaping like a dog at a sop suspended over his head, to get up Senate bill N 12 to refund the fine of General Jackson. He succeeded at last in getting a vote by yeas and nays, but the house refused 77 to 83 to take it up— Weller moved the vote of thanks to the Speaker Charles Brown in a huffy speech declared he would not vote for it. Pickens Charles J. Ingersoll, Wise and Cushing, voted for it from professed magnanimity— Wise after asking to be excused— T. F. Marshall asked to make a speech after midnight Not allowed. Adjourned without day at half past one A.M. leaving the Senate in Session, upon executive business. They sat till half past 2. and thrice rejected Wise and Cushing.

The scene has changed; but I yet find time neither for repose, nor for profitable occupation— A succession of visitors absorbed the day. First came George Brown, who informed me that he had received the appointment of commissioner to the Sandwich Islands— He told me that Edward Everett was appointed minister plenipotentiary to China— That Henry A. Wise was nominated three times to the Senate as Minister to France, and three times rejected. That Caleb Cushing, had been three times nominated Secretary of the Treasury with the same result, after which John C Spencer was nominated for Secretary of the Treasury, and confirmed by the majority of one vote— W. W. Irwin nominated chargé d’Affaires to Denmark was confirmed without much opposition— The vacancy in England by Edward Everett’s appointment to China, is the substitute for the special mission, which slumped through in the Committee of foreign affairs— It is the back door by which Webster skilfully secures to himself a safe retreat from the Tyler cabinet. If Everett declines the China Mission, Webster can take it himself.— William Claiborne the rattle-brained keeper of the Marshall house at Richmond, came and took leave; and shewed me several of his Letters of recommendation: Coll. Freeman of the Marine Corps came with a budget of grievance, but finding me engaged with others said he would call again on Monday— I met Mr Slade in the Street, as I was going to the Bank of the Metropolis— He spoke of the address to the people on the subject of Texas, which Mr Seth M. Gates, wished to leave with me, but finally took himself— Most of the other visitors came merely to take leave, save Lee and Tompkins, strangers, who came by the mere impulse of curiosity. Mr Briggs and Richard D. Davis came together. Connell was desponding. I had helped his bill for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton through the house, and he had sangwine hopes of its passage in the Senate—but its friends could not bring it up; though he says there were 30 members out of 50 ready to vote for it— Alexander Randall came for the trunk containing the papers of the late William Wirt; but while I was looking for the key, hurried away for fear of losing the 4. O’Clock Cars; saying he would come for it again— Day lost.

At the second Presbyterian church, morning and afternoon the services were performed by the Revd. Dr Ezra Stiles Ely formerly of Philadelphia, but now of some where in the State of Missouri; at once an aspirant to sanctity and hacknied in the ways of the world— In 1828 he prostituted his pulpit in Philadelphia, by presbyterian electioneering harangues to promote the election to the Presidency of Andrew Jackson, a recorded adulterer a duel murderer, and a ruffian blasphemer, but a pious and exemplary member of the presbyterian church— At that time, by Doctor Ely’s creed all the sins of orthodox presbyterians from the beginning of time, and all that are to come have been washed white in the blood of the lamb— A sin more or a sin less is of no account, when the atonement sweeps them all in one lump away.— Dr. Ely’s morning text was from Romans 10.11. [“]For the scripture saith, whosoever believeth on him shall not be ashamed”— The scripture quoted, he said was Isaiah 28.16. [“]he that believeth shall not make haste.” that is like persons who are ashamed— The whole sermon was an earnest and eloquent exhortation to the auditory, not to be ashamed of the belief in Christ— And there were many remarks on the nature of Faith, but without noticing its two fold meaning of mere belief and of fidelity— After the morning worship Mr Snelling called on me and I returned to him the Letter from Horace Mann the Secretary of the Massachusetts board of School commissioners which he had left with me, and in which he proposes a plan for the investment of the Smithsonian fund— Mr D. D. Barnard also called to take leave, intending to depart on his return home to Albany to-morrow.— This being the first Sunday in Lent, the communion was administered by Mr Hawley at St. John’s Church and there was no evening service there— I attended again at the 2d. Presbyterian church, where Dr. Ely preached from Titus 3.14. “And let ours also learn to maintain good works for necessary uses”—leaving out the remaining words of the verse—[“]that they be not unfruitful.” This was a very sensible and liberal discourse on the necessity of good works as the natural and universal result of faith, though of no avail whatever to salvation— The Doctor gave notice that he should preach again next Sunday morning and afternoon at the same church— His auditory this morning was very thin, but this afternoon the church was full, without being crowded— Four strangers in my pew— Evening visits from J. L. Kerr, ex-Senator from Maryland, and from R. D. Cutts. Mr Kerrs term has just expired and will not be renewed—

Coll. William H. Freeman of the Marine Corps, came this morning; and gave me a full exposition of the abusive treatment and persecution which he is suffering from Coll. Henderson the commandant of the corps— He believes it originated in a loan of money which Henderson obtained from him in 1834. and the payment of which he procrastinated and evaded till Freeman was obliged to demand it in a tone so peremptory and menacing that Henderson made the payment, and declared that all personal intercourse between them other than strictly official would thenceforward cease.— Two days after Freeman received an order, transferring him from Boston to Pensacola from the healthiest to the most unhealthy station of the service— To accomplish this petty tyranny Henderson got the numbers of the stations changed— And so feeble is the state of Freeman’s health that he has certificates from Dr Bigelow and another eminent physician at Boston that a summer residence in a Southern climate would imminently endanger his life— He has remonstrated against all this, first, with Henderson himself and afterwards with the Secretary of the Navy Upshur, with the result only of another transfer from Pensacola to Norfolk Virginia— He now asked my advice, as an old friend of his deceased wife’s father Rufus G. Amory and of his kinsman, the late Revd. Dr James Freeman.— I advised him to see Mr Webster, and to appeal directly to the President. I went to the Capitol; returned books to the house and Congress libraries, and brought home the Letters and papers left in my draw— Took at the document chamber the sheets of the house and Senate journals hitherto printed, and one or two spare documents— At the clerk’s office I enquired for the Resolution, which I reported from the Committee of foreign Affairs on the last Night of the Session, against the invasion of foreign territories by a military or naval officer, and which the house by yeas and naystorefused to suspend the rules to receive— It was mislaid and not to be found. I had received a note yesterday from the National Intelligencer Office requesting a copy of it, but I had none. I called at the office, where Mr Seaton gave me three Arkansas State Gazettes of 18 and 25 January and 1. February last containing the Sevier atchievements on the Smithsonian fund— This afternoon my neighbour Mr Parris called and invited me to spend this evening at his house with Mr John Holmes and his wife, a daughter of the late General Henry Knox, which I did. Mr Briggs had paid me a morning visit, with two young men, one named Colt, from Pittsfield, and the other M’Kay, a Grand Son of Samuel Dexter— A man named Elliot, from Harrisburg came to enquire about an appropriation for an agent at the Isthmus of Panama.

I am just now beginning to have some leisure for resuming the thread of events, though not for undertaking any useful occupation— Isaac Clark, Walter Hellen’s slave came for the contribution which I have promised and which I now gave him— Walter has given him permission to go to New-York and endeavour to raise a subscription there to pay for his freedom I have my misgivings that when he once gets there Walter will never see him again— Coll. Freeman came again and read to me the Letters which he has prepared to the Secretary of the Navy and to the President upon his case— He said he had called upon Mr Webster, and had solicited the exercise of his influence in his favour— Mr Webster he said approved of his application to the President, and advised him to ask me to give him a Letter of introduction to the President. I will not indulge a suspicion of the motive which could have prompted Webster to give that advice; but I told Coll. Freeman, that he might say to Mr Webster, and if he chose to the President himself, that my personal relations with him since the close of the second Session of this Congress, as would not permit me to give to any one a Letter of introduction to him— I called at the Globe Office and settled there my bill for a complete set of the Congressional Globe and Appendix, the only poor substitute for the Register of Debates in Congress since the suspension of that of Gales and Seaton in 1837. There are ten Quarto Volumes: and that of the recent Session will not be completed they tell me till after midsummer— Mr Haas a German who takes Daguerrotype likenesses in the Pennsylvania avenue near the capitol had engaged me to come and sit to his Camera obscura and I went this afternoon— But Mr Haas said the morning would be a more favourable time and I promised to call again to-morrow before Noon— This Evening the Count de Menou came to thank me for the assistance I gave to effect the passage of the Bill for the relief of the heirs of Philip Francis Renaut— Though unsuccessful, and the bill was rejected the Count’s expressions of gratitude were as fervent and cordial as they could have been if we had succeeded— Mr Richard Rush was here last evening and took leave of us. The bill for his relief was more fortunate and was carried through— His grateful acknowledgments were also very gratifying to me, and he was very earnest in his invitation that on our return home we would stop at Philadelphia to spend a day with him and his family at Sydenham—

The assortment and filing of my Letters which have been two months accumulating, some of them unread, occupies now about two hours of my time every day— Four hours, for the recording of two days in this Diary, to retrieve every day one of the arrears, gives as much writing as I can perform— The tide of visitors is subsiding, and the newspaper and pamphlet reading is not now overcharged as it was during the Session of Congress.—Mr James C. Adams, Secretary of the Baltimore Lyceum had written me a Letter from Brown’s hotel last evening, enquiring if I would deliver a Lecture before that institution; and he came this morning and renewed in person the invitation— I have no alternative, but to decline them all; and in every case it is a trial of temper to give a courteous negative answer. I walked this morning to Mr Haas’s shop, and he took from his camera obscura, three Daguerrotype likenesses of me— The operation is performed in half a minute; but is yet altogether incomprehensible to me. Mr Haas says it is a chemical process upon mercury, silver, gold and Iodine. It would seem as easy to stamp a fixed portrait from the reflection of a mirror; but how wonderful would that reflection itself be, if we were not familiarised to it from childhood.— I went to the Capitol, and on enquiry at the Clerk’s office, found that my resolution reported from the Committee of foreign Affairs in the night of the 3d. of March, but not received by the house, was recovered; a copy of it was furnished me, which I gave to Mr Gales for publication in the National Intelligencer— I met him in the Congress library.— There are no additional documents, or journals of the houses printed since Monday— The arrearages of printed Documents are enormous.— Those of the house even for the second Session of the recent Congress I am told will not be completed till next winter— Mr Danforth came again to enquire if I would deliver a Lecture at Alexandria— I definitively declined.— He asked me if I had heard Dr Ely at the second presbyterian church last Sunday; I said I had; and he intimated that perhaps the Doctor would incline to be permanently settled there— I received last evening a Letter from Charles J. Ingersoll at Philadelphia, reminding me of Letters received by me some months since from Dr Lamb of Frankford 6 miles from Philadelphia, inviting me to deliver a Lecture there— Charles was a strange correspondent to urge this invitation upon me; but I answered his Letter in all cordiality, and desired to be excused from delivering the Lecture— I wrote also to the Revd Obadiah B. Brown, concerning his note due next Saturday.

I received this morning a note from Mr Hagner requesting in behalf of Mr Alexander Randall the return of the trunk containing the papers of the late William Wirt which was accordingly done— It has been a year or more in my possession at the earnest request of Mrs Wirt, and her family to examine the papers and advise what portion of them should be published— A task which I have not been able to perform nor even to read more than a small part of an autobiography which I found very amusing. I regret very much being obliged now to give up the papers which are to be committed to Mr John P. Kennedy, for the same purpose. In looking over my papers I found several which required my attendance at the Departments of the Treasury and of War— I went first to the Treasury— The Secretary John C. Spencer, transferred from the War Department in the last hour of the late Congress after the thrice repeated rejection by the Senate of the nomination of Caleb Cushing, had taken possession of his new Office yesterday— He was to come in this day at 1. O’Clock— I returned to the chief clerk M’Clintock Young the Abstract of West-Florida claims, and the transcript of that of Joseph Mauro, which I had borrowed, for the illustration of David Levy’s bill, and which defeated it— I enquired if application had been made at the Department in behalf of Joshua Drew of Duxbury, for payment of the sum of 240 dollars granted for his relief by an act of the recent Session. No such application has been made, and I wrote to inform him that the act has passed— I had received a Letter from John Ford making enquiries concerning a supposed claim of Elisha Sprague of Marshfield deceased of indemnity for property destroyed by the Seminole Indians but not a trace of the claim could be found at the Department— I had taken Treasury Notes redeemable this and the past days since the 3d. but Mr Young informed me that they would be payable on the 1st. of July next at the merchant’s Bank in Boston, and I concluded to keep them for the present— Mr Young informed me that from 1. Jany. 1842 inclusive, no interest has been paid on the Smithsonian-Arkansas bonds—except about 4500 dollars, which came to the credit of that State, as her portion of the proceeds of the Sales of the public Lands— I went to the War Department and found there Mr Spencer, with his successor James Madison Porter, just installed as Secretary of War, in his place— I returned with Mr Spencer to his Office, and had a long conversation with him respecting the condition of the Smithsonian fund— Mr Hassler, and Mr Choate with Mr Davis here this Evening.

In the unceasing mill clapper talk of Mr Hassler last evening, he asked me to introduce him to the new Secretary of the Treasury John C. Spencer which I agreed to do, and appointed this day at one O’Clock to go with him to the Department for that purpose— He came and we went accordingly— I introduced him, and almost immediately left them together; but not without perceiving the seeds of a conflict already germinating between two proud spirits, which bodes no good to the progress of the Coast Survey.— The recent act places Hassler under the controul of a board of Officers; and the whole operation under the superintendence of the Secretary of the Treasury— Hassler, already restive under the yoke fitting to his neck, said that the work being scientific must be conducted on scientific principles— The potentate answered in a subdued tone of voice but with the trenchant stubbornness of authority the Laws must be obeyed— The pride of Science clashed with the pride of place, and I left them together.— I had observed the same temper in Spencer yesterday in talking with him about the present condition and prospects of the Smithsonian fund— I supplicated him to take an interest in the restoration, preservation and application of the fund to the purposes of the testator— He promised to make a full report to Congress on the subject—to recommend the issue of 6 per Cent stock of the United States to the full amount of the dilapidated funds and the investment of it in trustees— The Chief Justice of the United States and other Officers of the Government— But he thought the disposal of the funds should be left entirely to the Trustees, and he pronounced the prejudices against my plan of an astronimical observatory insurmountable because I had once called observatories, light houses in the skies— My words were light-houses of the skies, but Mr Spencer sees no difference between the two phrases— Mr Spencer turned up his eyes at the swindling speculation of the Senator from Arkansas, and shruged up his shoulders at the prospect of ever recovering the money from that State— I spent much of this day in transiently reading the report of the trial in the Supreme Court of the United States of the case of Edward Prigg against the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania—otherwise called the fugitive slave case— Seven judges—every one of them dissenting from the reasoning of all the rest, and every one of them coming to the same conclusion: the transcendent omnipotence of Slavery in these United States, riveted by a clause in the Constitution that persons held to labour, escaping from one State to another shall be delivered up on the claim of the person to whom the labour is due— David Lee Child and Richard D. Cutts in succession, occupied the hours of this Evening.

The Note of Obadiah B. Brown, which I took this time last year secured by a mortgage of lots in this city, was payable this day. I had neglected to have the mortgage Deed recorded within six months from its date as the law here requires— Day before yesterday I wrote to Mr Brown, enquiring, if I might expect payment this day— Yesterday I received his answer, promising to pay the interest, but asking further indulgence for the principal— I had engaged Major C. J. Nourse to procure for me a Cincinnati 6 per cent bond for 1000 dollars at 83 1/2 per cent and he came this morning to inform me that it would be delivered to me next Wednesday, to come from Philadelphia; but it was to be paid for this day— I therefore applied at the Treasury Department for repayment of two Treasury Notes of 500 dollars each, due on the 8th. of this month— The treasurer referred me to the Bank of the Metropolis, where they took my two Notes and gave me a credit of 1060 dollars and 49 cents— I then gave Major Nourse two checks—one for 835 dollars for the Cincinnati bond which he is to deliver to me next Wednesday, and one for 221.25 for which he is to deliver to me a city corporation note of 250 dollars— Upon all which I remark my own indiscretion in making the payments before the delivery of the stocks— An experiment somewhat hazardous, and not to be repeated— Upon my file of Letters which I am assorting I found two relating to Post Offices which required answers. One from Jesse Murdoch of Carver; and the other from John E. Boyden, an aspirant for a Post-Office at South Dedham— I took them to the general Post-Office— The Postmaster General Wickliffe was gone to escort homeward his Son, recently married to a daughter of Dawson the amiable bully from Louisiana— The first Assistant Postmaster General Hobbie was also absent. But Mr Whittlesey the auditor was there, and the second Assistant Postmaster General Bryant, whom I informed that Mr Murdoch’s Letter, recommended Samuel E. Shurtleff, for the appointment of Postmaster at Carver— Mr Bryant exhibited to me the papers in the Office relating to the application for an Office at South Dedham— There were two Letters from the Revd. Calvin Durfee of that place, one to me and one to his uncle Benjamin Tappan, Senator from Ohio, remonstrating against a new Office at South Dedham, because it would require the discontinuance of the existing Office at East-Walpole— I took the mortgage deed of Obadiah B. Brown to the City Hall and left it at the Register’s Office to be recorded— William Brent said there was an act of Congress remedying the laches of a record not made within the six Months— Call at Haas’s shop and took the Daguerrotype likeness of me—a very good one— At the House Clerk’s Office in the Capitol— No further Documents or journals printed— Mr O. B. Brown came this afternoon and paid me a year’s interest on his note, and for recording the mortgage.— And hopes to pay the note itself before midsummer.

I attended morning and afternoon at the second Presbyterian church and heard Dr Ezra Stiles Ely— His morning text was from Hebrews 5.9. “And being made perfect he became the author of eternal salvation unto all them that obey him.” This verse is in one of the most obscure and mysterious chapters of all the writings of St. Paul—if indeed which I much doubt the epistle to the hebrews was written by St. Paul— The allusions to Christ as a Priest forever after the order of Melchisedek—are utterly unintelligible to me— The quotation is from Psalm 110.4. a reference to which furnishes no elucidation. Dr Ely however took no notice of the context, but descanted largely upon the complicated humanity and divinity of Jesus Christ, a theme with which the most learned and accomplished gospel polemic never meddles but he finds no evil, in wandering mazes lost.— The Doctor’s afternoon text was from Proverbs 11.30.—“and he that winneth souls is wise[”]—omitting the first clause of the verse— The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life— He said that the word winneth implied the natural depravity of mankind; for it must be some wickedness or evil propensity from which the soul was to be won.—and then he discoursed upon the wisdom to be exercised in winning souls from the errors of their ways— Now came the atonement, and a slight touch at the doctrine of universal Salvation— He said he had not so read his bible.— And he undertook to declare with undoubting confidence, how the righteous on earth will meet and recognize and enjoy the Society of their old acquaintances in heaven—a pretension rather presumptuous.— The Doctor’s manner of preaching is agreeable— Without notes— In the style of familiar conversation— Not at all ambitious of oratory, without figurative ornaments— Argumentative—earnest—copious, without superfluity of words.—calmly eloquent, but never transporting—nor transported— The house as on the last Sunday was very thin on the morning, but well filled in the afternoon— He had been desired to request the members of the congregation to remain a few minutes after the service, which they did—at this meeting Mr M’Lellan proposed that Dr. Ely should be invited to settle as the Pastor of the Church.— It met with general assent, and a committee of 3 members was appointed to confer with him on the subject— If they can agree with him, notice is to be given at the Church next Sunday that an election of a Pastor will be held in the course of the then ensuing week. The Doctor is weary of Missouri, and peradventure Missouri is weary of him. Stephen D. Smith and passed Midshipman Joseph H Adams dined with us, and Richard D. Cutts, and his Sister Mary were here at tea.

Coll. Freeman came this morning, under great excitement— He had not been able to see the President, but had received this morning from the Secretary of the Navy Abel P. Upshur an order in the harshest official style, saying that no change will be made in the stations of the Officers of the marine Corps—commanding him to repair to his Post at Norfolk and adding that at the end of the month he might renew his application for leave of absence if he saw fit. The Coll. has certificates from Doctors Bigelow and Jeffries of Boston and Dr Thompson of Charlestown would endanger his life, and he thinks there is personal malevolence against him among the motives of the Secretary: he says that was the impression upon Richard Peters who undertook as Freeman’s friend to expostulate with the Secretary in his favour.— The Colonel intimated that he might take his own leisure as to the time when he would go to Norfolk, and in the meantime would urge earnestly his appeal to the President— I advised him to be very cautious to do nothing that might be construed into a breach of discipline, remarking that the slightest colour of that, would be seized with avidity and turned against him. I promised to call immediately upon Mr Webster, and endeavour to obtain his influence to mitigate the prejudices against him— I went accordingly forthwith to the Department of State and saw Mr Webster— I returned to him a confidential despatch which he had lent me in January last; from Edward Everett, dated in November 1842 immediately after the reception in England of the News of the Peace with China— And I said I had been much gratified with the appointment of Edward Everett as the Minister to China; deeming the mission of transcendent importance, and deeming him by his character and attainments peculiarly well suited for such a mission— Mr Webster appeared to be much delighted, and they appeared to be quite unexpected— He immediately said he would be greatly obliged to me, if I would write as much to Edward Everett himself, which I said I would do with pleasure— He asked me to send the Letter to him to-morrow, when the despatches would be made up to go by the Great Western, next Thursday. though her arrival at New-York is not yet known— After this I spoke to him of the complaint of Coll Freeman and intreated him to take an interest in it, so far as to obtain relief for him if possible; which he promised with apparent cordiality— He said he would speak this evening to Mr Upshur and to-morrow morning to the President, but it will be to no purpose— Coll. Freeman was here again this afternoon and said he should go for Norfolk to-morrow.— Dr Thomas paid us a visit, and Dr Frye dined with us—

A religious Monomaniac by the name of Miller has been preaching and lecturing and prophesying the second advent of Christ and the end of the world or otherwise the kingdom of the Saints for many months, and as such insanities are always infectious, he has frightened multitudes, some to convulsions and death, others into piety and penitence—and many to uneasiness of mind more or less disguised— The first prediction was that the general conflagration would kindle on the 23d. of April of this present year— As the day approaches he has become less precise in the indication of time, and announces the Catastrophe, as to be consummated on or within one year from that day.— To quicken the sensation of alarm, within the last fortnight, the portentous tail of a Comet, some sixty degrees in length, has swept the South western horizon, every clear evening after the setting of the sun— The nucleus has been here hidden behind the disk of that luminary, and has not been seen, though paragraphs of distant newspapers aver that it has been seen in broad day, near the sun, and in brightness equal to that of the planet Venus— My obstinate and inexorable catarrh awoke me this morning before 3. and delayed my rising hour till 6— The day was one of uninterrupted leisure and yet of no performance— I wrote last a Letter to Edward Everett to persuade him to accept the mission to China and sent the Letter this day to the Department of State.— I read the Message of the President to the Senate of 24. Feby last in answer to two of their Resolutions, calling for the correspondence relating to the Quintuple Treaty, on the 13th. of June 1842 The house of Representatives at my motion adopted a similar Resolution, including a copy of the Treaty—on the 20th. of that same month John Tyler answered the Resolution, refusing the correspondence at that time, declaring a hope and expectation that he will find it convenient to communicate it at an early day; and containing these words—“In answer to this request, I have to say that the treaty mentioned therein has not been officially communicated to the Government of the United States, and no authentic copy of it, therefore can be furnished”— In this present message to the Senate the first Document is a Letter from Daniel Webster to Cass, dated 5. April 1842 in which he says—the President has been closely attentive to recent occurrences in Europe connected with the treaty of the five powers, of which we received a copy soon after its signature in December— Is there an escroc in a penitentiary who could match that for prevarication? The correspondence between Webster and Cass is tart and curious enough— Guizot’s Letter in answer to Cass’s absurd protest is a chef d’oeuvre— I walked to the Office of the National Intelligencer and held some conversation with Mr Seaton— Whiled away much of the day in assorting papers—

Another restless, hacking, racking night— I awoke coughing before 3 this morning, and lay till a quarter past 4. without sleeping and impatient to rise; but for an idle and drowsy day. I walked to the shop of Mr Haas where I found a young man with two ladies his wife and her companion whose likenesses he took in a group while I was there— He attempted also to take me, but did not succeed, because he said there was too much light of the Sun; and I promised to come again to morrow or the first fair day between 8 and 9 of the morning. I went to the document room, and Clerk’s Office of the House of Representatives, and found a few additional documents, of which I took some, but the printing both of journals of the recent Session is enormously in arrear; and the House Documents even of the Session before the last will not be completed for months— The two reports from the Committee of Commerce, on the treatment of coloured mariners in our Southern ports are at last delivered, and I addressed and despatched about 40 of them to friends in the late 12th and present 8th. congressional district of Massachusetts— The correspondence about the quintuple Treaty and the right of search.; has at once amused and provoked me not a little.— Its illustration of character, is admirable— Cass’s protest of 13. Feby 1842. against the ratification by France of the Treaty signed and sealed by her own Ambassador, is a compound of yankee cunning, of Italian perfidy and of French legeraté cemented by shameless profligacy unparalleled in American diplomacy— Tyler’s approval of it is at once dishonest, mean, insincere, and hollow-hearted— Cass’s correspondence with Webster, is insolent, inconsistent, sophistical, and prevaricating; and Guizot’s answer of 26. May, to his protest of 13. Feby. is not only a complete refutation of its absurd assumptions, but a most contemptuous exposure of its glaring falsehood— It is a silent but not the less severe rebuke upon President Tyler’s approval of this preposterous counterfeit of a State paper.— It is wretchedly printed in the official document, and still worse translated— Coming home I met judge Henry Baldwin of the U.S. supreme Court who told me that he just came from my house where he had called to pay a visit before returning home— The Court closed their annual Session yesterday; and this afternoon Henry Young the Crier of the Court came to beg two dollars to save him from starving.— Mrs Thornton and Mrs Talbot spent part of the Evening here, and Mrs Goods’s daughter Mitchell with her husband was burnt out; the second time within a week and the third time within two years— I answered Revd. E. W. Davies of Dayton Ohio, with copies of the Sanwich Island and China Documents, and a second Letter from James B. Murray asking the return of the Mississippi Bond.

The progress of my Catarrh continues with increasing severity— After a foot bath last evening, I was roused from sleep before 3 this morning, by a fit of coughing, and after rising for about ten minutes returned to bed but not to rest till after 5— According to promise I walked up to Mr Haas’s shop about 9. my hands in woolen lined gloves, bitterly pinched with cold. found Horace Everett there, for the same purpose of being fac simileed. Haas took him once, and then with his consent took me three times—the second of which he said was very good—for the operation is delicate: subject to many imperceptible accidents; and fails at least twice out of three times.— I then left them and walked to the Capitol, a flake of snow falling here and there as I went. My first visit was to the office of the Secretary of the Senate—Dickins was not there, but Hickey was.— I asked to see the manuscript documents of the Message to the Senate concerning the Quintuple Treaty—especially the copy of Guizot’s Letter to Cass of 26. May 1842— I found that some of the errors in the printed copy were not in the manuscript; but other evident errors were— But the greatest and most disreputable errors were in the translation. I pointed them all out to Hickey who said they must have the document printed over again—but even that will not cover the shame of the false translation— From the Secratariat of the Senate, I went into the Congress library and returned the first volume of Peter Pindar, which I had borrowed—and I found there two other books charged to me; for which I must account— Thence I went into the military Committee room of the Senate where I found J. M. Edwards, another Daguerrotype likeness taker. I had received last evening a note from him, requesting me to come this day or to morrow between 9 and 3, as he wanted my likeness for a large picture of the Senate chamber, which he has projected and in which the Senators, judges of the Supreme Court, the President, and his Cabinet and others may all be assembled— But it was now snowing apace— Mr Edwards said he could not take my likeness this day, but asked if I could not stop to be taken at New-York on my way home. I declined, and on inspecting many samples of the faces he had taken, I was glad to be released from being taken by him at all. I travelled through the driving snow to the Office of the National Intelligencer, where I saw Mr Gales, and advised him to print in his paper the Letter from Guizot to Cass, correctly from the original I asked him also for the Intelligencer of the 11th containing Cushing’s speech on the execution of the Ashburton Treaty, to which is annexed a copy of the Quintuple Treaty—which he gave me. I made my way home through the Snow, which continued to fall the whole day through—more than has fallen at one time for many years.

The Snow fell, about one foot deep on the level and drifted in many places to be four feet deep, so that with my cough upon me, I was confined to the house the whole day. Coll. Freeman whom I had met yesterday in the Street, and who then told me that he was coming to me again upon his affairs came according this morning and stated his purposes— He said that Mr Webster had brought the matter before the cabinet, though apparently without success— His own explanations had been with Fletcher Webster, the Secretary’s Son and Chief Clerk, who course has reported all the statements to his father—but the Coll. has no relaxation from his order to repair to his post at Norfolk— He read to me what he proposed to write as his final reply to the Secretary of the Navy; and then his last appeal to the President— He proposes then to go to Norfolk—remain there till the end of this month— Then to renew the demand to be restored to the post at Boston, and to return there without waiting for further orders— I advised him not to do that, but to wait for the President’s answer to his appeal, and if that should be against him to remain at Norfolk two or three months till the approach of the sickly season, and then to renew the application for removal to a northern station— I advised him also to leave out of his applications to the Secretary of the Navy and to the President every word that could possibly deemed disrespectful— He served in the Constitution frigate in the last War with Great-Britain; with Bainbridge at the capture of the Java, and with Stuart at the taking of the Levant and Cyane.—

I have at last constituted myself a sick man, and sent for Doctor Thomas Last night, as the Night before I was twice roused from bed before the time of rising for the day, and the oppression of my cough on the lungs has become insupportable. The Doctor came and prescribed for this Night— I keep my chamber, and all my plans of studious labour, are indefinitely postponed— I read the strange Speech of John C. Clark on the Bill appropriating 40000 dollars, for establishing a diplomatic intercourse with China; which is an invective of wormwood and gall against the Secretary of State— He has published it in a pamphlet, and it had long been studiously devised— The charges against him are stale and hacknied. His Treachery to the whig party, in refusing to resign with the other members of the Harrison Cabinet in August 1841.— His adhesion to Tyler, and jobbing with him for re-election, with a condition that Tyler should support him for the succession, but above all the Faneuil Hall Speech, were the irremissible sins, for which Mr Clarke administers this castigation.— I thought it in bad taste when delivered— It reads to me now inexpressibly flat stale and unprofitable— Clark is a New-York Politician of the Clinton and Livingston school—in comparison with that of John Jay, ratsbane to ambrosia— Walter Hellen was here this evening.— I had laid out for myself steady and I hoped useful occupation till the advance of the spring shall call us home for the summer—but I am now annihilated for labour morning and evening, and have no power to apply to my condition any faculty of more active energy than Patience and resignation.

Twice up in the night, and convulsed the whole day in casting off phlegm from the stomach what a disgusting object to himself is a man? It is difficult to contemplate the infirmities of our physical nature philosophically— Every thing about sickness is odious to the sufferer and annoying to those around him— There is a consolation in the kindness of nursing friends; but the primary grief and self-reproach to me is the loss of time— I am idle— As the hours pass in succession I know, I might be working— I brood over projected labours and never commence working— As morning dawns, I have a long day before me, and think I shall use it to some good purpose— It slips away, I know not how— Approaching midnight summons me to repose—and I have lost a day.

lg.l: I’ve lost a day—the Prince who nobly said—
Had been an Emperor without his crown.

div.p: The globe of earth has not space for the surface of Empires over which I should be worthy to rule if I could proclaim the record of my lost days. Mr Matthew St. Clair Clark came to visit me, but I was accidently not informed of it, and did not see him. After tea, and a game of back-gammon, with Louisa, and a rubber at whist with the three generations. Mr David Lee Child came in and spent the evening with me till past 11. He brought with him and shewed me an extract of a Letter in Spanish from a Mexican Commissioner; at La Guayra, on his way to attend a meeting of Envoys from the South American Governments and Mexico, to be held at Lima in Peru; and of which I had never before heard— The Letter is addressed to General Almonte, this Mexican Minister here, who gave the extract to Child to use it, as he might think proper. Almonte had caused to be printed here at the commencement of the last Session of Congress two pamphlets, one containing the spicy correspondence between the United States and Mexico from 12. May to 10 September 1842. and the other entitled Texas, consisting of extracts from my address at Braintree, of 17. Septr. 1842, with translations of the same into French and Spanish— The Letter from La Guayra, acknowledges the receipt of this last pamphlet; speaks of the address in terms of high commendation, and says he will transmit it to the principal cities of the several South American Republics for circulation there— Childs further told me, that in the month of January last, Webster actually proposed to Almonte a cession to the United States by Mexico of a portion of territory on the pacific Ocean, including the Port of San Francisco: so as to allow the British Government to stretch their territory down to the mouth of the Columbia river.— This is a ray of light—serving to explain Webster’s desire that Edward Everett should go to China, and he himself to England. Child says Almonte told him that Mexico had no disposition to part with any portion of her territory.— Webster’s political profligacy is gigantic.

I have this day been debarred by my disease from the privilege of attendance upon public worship; and felt it with deep mortification. The time has been, chiefly in foreign countries when I have too long intermitted the duty of that attendance— Of this I charge myself especially when in Holland, in Berlin, in St. Petersburg, and last in France— I have lost by it rich opportunities of obtaining instruction; not only religious, but worldly, moral, political, intellectual— For this I blame myself; but the importance of regular attendance upon the duties of the Christian Sabbath in social communion has impressed itself more deeply on my mind in proportion as I have advanced in years.— I had neglected to become a member of the church, till after the decease of my father—another omission which I now regret I have at all times been a sincere believer in the existence of a supreme creator of the world, of an immortal principle within myself responsible to that creator for my conduct upon earth; and of the divine mission of the crucified saviour, proclaiming immortal life and preaching peace on earth, good will to men, the natural equality of all mankind, and the Law, thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself— Of all these articles of faith, all resting upon the first, the existence of an omnipotent Spirit, I entertain involuntary and agonizing doubts, which I can neither silence nor expel, and against which I need for my own comfort to be fortified and sustained, by stated and frequent opportunities of receiving religious admonition and instruction— I feel myself to be a frequent sinner before God; and I need to be often admonished of it and exhorted to virtue. This is administered in all the forms of Christian worship, and I am sure of receive it with whatever denomination of Christian worshippers I associate to obtain it— Of late years I have deemed it my duty to attend the weekly morning performances of the Chaplains of Congress in the Hall of the House of Represenentatives; and I hold pews at St John’s episcopal church and at the second Presbyterian church, at which I attend alternately when Congress are not in session, and in the afternoon when they are— This forms a regular portion of my habits of life, and I cannot feel the privation of it without painful sensibility— My time hung heavy upon my hands. Joseph H. Adams dined with us and Richard D Cutts was here in the afternoon.— After tea my granddaughter Mary Louisa read to me some pages in Plutarch’s Life of Pericles, and some pages in Virgil Maxcy’s life of John C. Calhoun— The contrast between an antient, and a modern Statesman— I have also been reading a melancholy but very ingenious lecture delivered by Ezekiel Bacon before a Society of young men in New-York State, Utica entitled Recollections of Fifty years Since.

Extract from Niles Register of March 11. 1843. In a debate in the British house of PeersFeby 1843. upon the Queen’s speech, the Duke of Wellington spoke of the War and its origin. In answer to the Marquis of Lansdown he said; [“]I beg the noble marquis to recollect that I was almost the only individual in this house who stated that the real ground of complaint against the Chinese government was its conduct towards persons employed in the service of her majesty and representing her majesty, upon the occasion when a motion upon the subject was made by my noble friend near me. I was almost the only person in the house who defended her majesty’s servants in China, and I say the war was a just and a proper one on the part of her majesty’s government. (Cheers.) I go further and I say, that if it had been a War solely on the score of the robbery of the Opium, finding that her majesty’s Government was engaged in that War, and finding that the interest, and honour of the country were involved in that war, I should have considered it my duty, to make every effort to carry it on with the best means.”

My distempered, secluded and confined condition has left me no interesting occurrences for the materials of a Diary record, and despondency creeping over me threatens the disruption of this journal to be resumed only when my unclouded reason shall return to me by the will of the supreme disposer. The above extract from a Speech of the Duke of Wellington I have copied to keep on hand, in defence of my roughly handled Lecture of Novr. 1841. on the War between Great Britain and China— This day I find in a subsequent number of Niles Register, that of last Saturday Reports of a Speech of Lord Brougham on the Right of Search and our abortive Treaty with England of 1824—and of long debates in the French Legislative chambers recently resumed on the right of Search, between France and England; their treaties of 1831 and 1833, and the quintuple Treaty of 20 December 1841. yet unratified by France— There is much matter for curious observation and grave meditation on these recent controversies relating to the right of visitation and of search— Would it not be well to enquire into the right of maritime visitation and search, 1. by the Law of Nature? 2. by the practice of Antient Nations and as modified by the practice of piracy 3. By the practices of modern Nations, as modified by the doctrine of the mere clausum— 4. The new question started by the Negotiations of Great Britain to obtain the right the right of search for the suppression of the African Slave trade— 5. To mark the mistakes of both parties in precision of ideas bearing on the subject 6. The motives to dissension 7. The pretexts for opposition. 8 the political bearings of the subject— I received also this day a Letter from R. G. Beasley, at Havre 24 Jany 1843. with a pamphlet, to decry the English emancipation of Slaves, by its results, published by Jollivet, a member of the French chamber of deputies, from Martinique— Mrs Cutts here at tea— Whist—

Still confined to the house, and under medical discipline Having undertaken to produce a general perspiration last night, by a warm foot bath followed by three successive doses of antimonial wine and nitre taken through the Night at two hours distance from each other— It was a failure— Heat was produced but no perspiration— The heat passed off, and I remain with a loaded stomach but without fever— Mr Root of West Springfield and Mr Howard of New-York were morning visitors—Strangers— Merely wishing to see me— And judge Cranch, my cousin my boy companion, school and college mate and friend, came to compare notes of decrepitude between us.— The judge is my junior by two years, but suffers by the infirmity of years still more than I, and the sight of him is one of those admonitions which multiply upon me, and which I struggle in vain to discard— The controversy between Lewis Cass and Daniel Webster, about the Ashburton Treaty, the rights of visitation and of search and the Quintuple Treaty, still with the comet, the zodiacal light and the Millerite prediction of the second advent of Christ, and the end of the world within five weeks from this day continue to absorb much of the public and of my attention.— The intelligencer of this day announces another Letter from Cass to Webster who in his last Letter declares the correspondence closed— This strange correspondence— The debates in the French Legislative chambers, and in both houses of the British Parliament and in both houses of Congress but especially in the Senate— This Slave trade and right of search complicated with the quintuple Treaty, with Texas—Mexico, California, Oregon, and the next Presidential election, breed teeming fancies in my brain till I grope to find my way out of the thicket— I looked up this afternoon J. C. Calhoun’s 3. Resolutions of the U.S. Senate of 4. March 15. April 1840. the preposterous claims of indemnity for the liberated slaves of the Enterprize—voted unanimously by 22 slave breeders and 11 craven democrats—with 15 more craven spirits absent, skulking from the questions upon which they dared not vote either yea or nay. I looked also into Ward and Vattel to ascertain the right of visitation and search upon the Ocean.— The right of visitation is by the Law of Nature, an intercourse of mutual benefit, like that of strangers meeting in a wilderness— The right of search is for pirates in peace and for enemies in War— But I must look into the Mare Clausum and the Mare liberum. The right of property in the Ocean and upon the shores— Its extent and its limitations— And especially remember that—the present disputes about the right of search are all now questions all originating in the measures devised by the British Government for the suppression of the Slave trade— Night coming on arrested me in my consultations of Ward and Vattel, and in my search to trace the fortune of the claim for indemnity for the slaves of the Enterprize, from its belligerent claim by Calhoun in March 1840 to its tacit surrender, merged in the Negotiations of the Ashburton Treaty, and the more critical case of the Creole— Dr Thomas was here this Evening. Mary quite unwell—

The progress of my disease is obviously much affected by the various changes of the atmosphere— A week of confinement to the house I have already endured— On Thursday the 16th. I walked to the Capitol for exercise, my practice of which has for the last year or more been too much remitted.— Much, as I believe to the impairing of my health— I walked from the Capitol to the National Intelligencer Office, and afterwards thence home, last Thursday, through the severest Snow-storm that has been witnessed here, for perhaps seven years— Having then upon me a racking catarrh of several weeks standing. I have been confined from that day to the house: against my own will, for I should have preferred to be two or three hours of every day abroad, and the average of the weather has marked the temperature of January rather than that of March.— Last Night, and this day it had become milder, and was approaching the spring like; the masses of drifted snow in the Streets gradually settling into puddles, till about noon; when a sudden turn brought back the Northwester with another flight of snow; and then a clear sky, a bright Moon, a brisk gale, and a hard frost. I still keep house. Coll. Freeman was again here this morning.— He has sent his Letters to the Secretary of the Navy Upshur, and to the President—but has no answer from either— He would have gone for Norfolk yesterday—but the Steamer was detained and will not go till Friday. Lieutenant Thom of the topographical engineers, one of the young acquaintances of my nephew Isaac Hull spent the Evening with us—quite a pleasant young man— I re-examined the correspondence of Stevenson and Lord Palmerston, on the cases of the Comet, Enterprise and Encomium—leaving much more for persevering enquiry—and the whole enquiry shaped and methodised for a result— The same as to the project for refunding Andrew Jackson’s fine— An outrage upon Law, Justice, humanity, and all the principles of freedom, defeated in the last Congress and to be perpetrated in the next.— I reviewed also the two Volumes of Documents relating to Texas and Mexico—with reference to the late invasion of California, to the defeated bill for the occupation of the Territory of Oregon, and to the future Negotiations with England—upon all which I have much to learn, to do, and to suffer, to discharge the remainder of my duties upon earth— I took up too, the life of John C. Calhoun, by Virgil Maxcy, and Robert M. T. Hunter, just published, to puff him up into the line of Candidates for the Presidency— If the devil should incline to be set up as a candidate for the quadrennial chair, I would advise him to employ Virgil Maxcy and Robert M. T. Hunter to write his life— John C. Calhoun—President of the United States!— He is fit only to clean the boots of Thomas H. Benton in Pandemonium, after one of their pigmy transformations. Wanting some whipd syllabub information about Mexico, I asked Mary to borrow for me the two Volumes of Life in Mexico, recently published by Madame Calderon de la Barca.

Another Letter from Lewis Cass to Daniel Webster, about the Ashburton Treaty, the right of visitation and search, and the offended dignity of the aforesaid Lewis Cass at the Lordly tone assumed by the Secretary of State in the previous part of this correspondence— I am thinking if there is any thing parallel to this correspondence in our diplomatic history. Silas Deane came home from France and made a rumpus (that word is not in Webster’s Dictionary—what a pity!) for several years; blew up a flame which kept this union long in a phease (another Websterless word) and has left a large claim of his heirs and legal representatives, against the United States of which not a dollar is due, but which on some lucky day they will recover— Mr James Monroe was recalled by President Washington, through Timothy Pickering, wire worked by Alexander Hamilton— Mr Monroe published a volume of his correspondence—against the administration of Washington by whom he had been appointed and recalled—which book largely contributed to the fall of Washington’s Administration as continued by his successor— It helped to bring in the Jefferson Administration, which laid the foundation for the dissolution of the Union. Cass and Webster are both New-Hampshire adventurers, who have made their way in the world, by mere dint of talents, Figaro fashion, making a trade of politics, and a Lottery prize of their Country— Cass has got along by a series of Executive appointments, from Marshal of Ohio in March 1807 and 11. Colonel and Brigadier General in 1813. Governor of Michigan in 1814 and continued untill appointed Secretary of War in 1833 and Minister to France in 1836. While Governor of Michigan, by successful land jobbing he is said to have realized a fortune of more than 800000 dollars, which on the occasion of his mission to France he withdrew from the falling chances of speculation, and which has enabled him to live in France in the Style of an Ambassador, and to ingratiate himself with Louis Philippe, which he had done by servile sycophancy till this protest of 13. Feby. a perfect Joab-like stab under the 5th rib, as perfidious towards Louis Philippe and his Minister Guizot, as it was rash and desperate, with regard to his own Country, and hollow-hearted and treacherous as a man.— Webster too has the soul and manners of a parvenu. In this controversy Cass is outrageously wrong from beginning to end: but in permitting Tyler to approve Cass’s protest, Webster put into Cass’s hand a scourge which Cass now plies against him with merciless dexterity.— The fragment end of the 6th column of the National Intelligencer is a short note from Webster to Cass repelling an imputation that he had reserved his fire till after Cass was gone home and sent the shot after him— Webster says the President has directed that the correspondence here after must not be official— Cass sent three copies of this enormous lampoon at once; one to Webster himself, one to the Globe and one to the National Intelligencer; the two last for publication— The life of John C. Calhoun cooled me down, and Madame Calderon’s Life in Mexico refrigerated me— Dr Thomas was here and softened the tedious evening.

Eighth day of confinement to the house, and of time if not entirely wasted; lost for the purposes to which I had devoted it, and leaving a blank for all useful purposes— I intended to have called this morning at the Department of State; but I wasted so much time in looking up the traces of Jackson’s Negotiations with Mexico for Texas and San Francisco that the hour for visiting the public offices upon business passed away, and I must wait another day.— Anthony Butler’s mission to Mexico was chiefly to obtain the cession of Texas— His Letter to Jackson dated Mexico 15. April 1830. (Omnibus 3. 323) contains the first promise of success— His next Letter of 25 May 1831. (p. 381.) is apologetic and less encouraging.— The next despatch of 16. July 1832. to the then Secretary of State Livingston encloses minutes of two conversations of Butler with the Mexican Secretary of State Alaman, after which a written proposition dated 15 July 1832. was delivered to Alaman, but has never been made public— From that time till 26. February 1835— Butler was mistifying Jackson, as he boasted he was doing with Alaman, promising nothing, but leaving him not without hopes. The Letter of 26. February 1835. (p. 555—) is the crowning mystification; about 2 months after which Butler came to Washington where on the 17th. of June he made his proposals— They also are among the missing papers— There are two subsequent instructions from John Forsyth Secretary of State to Butler of 2 July and 6. Augt. 1835— In the first of which he is told that from his own accounts no confidence is entertained of the success of his negotiation: but that as he is sangwine of succeeding in a very short time he may go and try his luck again—but that he must despatch his whole business with expedition and have the result ready to be laid before Congress by the 1st. of December then next— And that it is expected he will himself immediately after return home. He goes accordingly back to Mexico— Writes two dalling despatches to notify that he cannot finish his business in quite so short a time as he had expected; and on the 15th. of January 1836 (p. 573) receives notice dated 16 December 1835 apprizing him that he has been superseded by the appointment of another person— It was in a despatch of 6. Augt. 1835. That Forsyth instructed him to propose the Rio Bravo to the 37th. parallel of Latitude, and along that parallel to the pacific—the main object being to secure within our limits the whole Bay of San Fransisco.— Butler tells him he has mistaken the Geography, and that the place he means in called Puerto Antonio Nuevo, within which is a Small town called San Francisco—and this is the San Francisco, for which Captain Tyler’s mouth waters— Morning visit from David L. Child, and Matthew St. Clair Clark spent a long evening with me— Joseph H. Adams was here before dinner. Dr Thomas intermitted.

At last, after eight whole days of confinement to the house, I made out to reach the Department of State, and had a three hours conversation with the Secretary Daniel Webster There was in the National Intelligencer of this morning an editorial article of 4 1/2 columns written by Webster himself on the Convention of March 1824. between the U.S. and Great Britain for the suppression of the African Slave-trade— It refers to the recent debates in both Houses of the British Parliament and both chambers of the French Legislature upon the right of Search; and especially to a speech of Lord Brougham on the 7th. of last month in the British house of peers contesting statements just before made by Monsieur Dupin in the French Chamber of Deputies concerning this identical Convention— The main object of the Article is to show, that the Senate of 1824 did in the most unequivocal manner concede this right of search— It gives the yeas and nays in the Senate on the question of advice and consent, with the names of A. Jackson and Thomas H. Benton in the affirmative— I asked to see the manuscript copy transmitted by General Cass to the Department of Mr Guizot’s Letter of 25. May 1842 to him, in answer to his protest of 13. February; and he made up a packet of it; with a despatch to Edward Everett prepared, but not yet forwarded, to be read to Lord Aberdeen and a copy of it to be furnished him if he desires it: being the quip modest, to the Letter from Lord Aberdeen, which Mr Fox by his order read to Webster in his Office about a month ago— This despatch to Everett is in Webster’s best style, and makes a direct issue with Lord Aberdeen and Sir Robert Peel on the point that there is by the Laws of Nations no clear, explicit and avowed distinction between the right of visitation, and the right of search. Also a long Letter of Instructions dated 15 March 1843. to Commodore Matthew C. Perry, going out as commander of the eighty gun squadron to be kept on the coast of Africa— To these he added the 11th volume of Wheaton’s Reports containing the adjudged case of the Mariana Flora in 1826— I spoke of Genl Cass’s recent outbreaks against him, but he did not appear inclined to discourse upon that subject— It was clear he remembered the Call of the house of the 13th. of June last year for copies of the Quintuple Treaty with Cass’s Correspondence, and the President’s refusal of them on the 28th. It is curious that Cass’s despatch with Guizot’s answer to the protest, was received on the 22d. of June— I spoke of the Senate Bill for the occupation of the Oregon Territory, of Ap-Catesby Jones’s exploit at Monterey; of the movements in and about Texas, and I suddenly asked him if Waddy Thompson had been instructed to negotiate for the acquisition of California— He faltered and said he did not know whether he could answer that question consistently with his official duty— I told him his declining to answer was answer enough for me, and we had warm and almost, not quite, angry words— I kept my temper, but pressed him more closely upon his declining to answer
answer my question, than was comfortable to him— He had begun by professing profound confidence in me—and in communicating his own instruction to Edward Everett, and Upshur’s to Commodore Matthew C. Perry, had said he would open to me Administra Secrets— Why he should now stop short and roll himself up in mystery upon the plea of official duty he did not explain— I saw he was deceiving me, and the danger of trusting him, and that it behooved me above all things to be upon my guard. I said I would not press him to divulge any administration secret that he was inclined to withhold— That he had volunteered the confidence of administration secrets; and I could not see why they should be tendered on one point of the system of foreign affairs and denied on another— I considered all the questions about the right of search—the bill for the occupation of the Oregon territory. Captain Jones’s movement on Calefornia, and all the movements for the annexation of Texas, were parts of one great system looking to a War for conquest and plunder from Mexico, and a War with England—and alliance with France— And I referred to Wise’s Speech of 14. April last avowing this project of a War with Mexico for conquest and plunder together with a War with Great Britain— I said Wise had blabed the whole project last April; and it could not pass without notice that that same Henry A. Wise had in the last hours of the late session of Congress been three times nominated to the Senate as Minister to France. It was also not less remarkable that Wise had been the confidential correspondent of Commodore Jones and had stated on the floor of the house that he had received from Jones himself a Letter in justification of his occupation of Monterey— Webster said I was wrong in all this— That Jones’s movement on Calefornia, was a freak of his own brain without any authority or instruction whatever That Wise’s speech (of which he had no knowledge) was a vain and senseless bravado— That with regard to the annexation of Texas, his decided opinion against the measure had long been public—he had not changed it, and it never could be effected by him, or with his consent.— I replied with warmth, till at last he told me that he had talked over the Oregon question with Lord Ashburton— That England wanted to come down on the Coast of the Pacific, to the mouth of the Columbia river— And that the question had been put to him, whether if a cession from Mexico South of our present boundary 42, to include the Port of San Francisco could be obtained, England would make any objection to it—and Lord Ashburton thought she would not— I thanked Mr Webster, for thus much of communication, and said I would now press the enquiry no further— I propose to visit the Department again next Monday.— But what an abyme of duplicity? We had a very small take leave evening party to Mr and Mrs Roosevelt— Mrs Seaton and her family and two or three others here.

At the second Presbyterian church this morning the Revd. R. R. Gurley Secretary of the Colonization Society, preached from Luke 17.20. [“]And when he was demanded of the Pharisees when the kingdom of God should come, he answered them and said, The kingdom of God cometh not with observation: 21. Neither shall they say, Lo here! or Lo there! for behold, the kingdom of God is within you.”— The discourse had a slight allusion to a popular panic extensively prevailing at this time and in this Country—raised and propagated by a man named William Miller; who by a profound study of the bible prophesies has patched up a prediction of his own, that the end of the world is at hand— I have received I know not from whom several pamphlets and hand bills on this subject and among them a small duodecimo Volume entitled Evidence from Scripture and History of the second coming of Christ about the year 1843. exhibited in a course of Lectures, by William Miller. The Lectures are 19. in number, and have been repeatedly delivered by Miller in various parts of this Country— On the covering page of the Book is a printed notice that the Vision began 457. years B.C. and ends in 1843.— There is in the book a profuse expenditure of ingenuity of close logic, of biblical criticism, of sacred and profane history; like the Russian palace of ice, built to celebrate a marriage of dwarfs— Mr Gurley did not make much of his text; nor is it very clear what is meant by the kingdom of God, in this passage— It would seem to be the same thing as the days of the Son of man, afterwards repeatedly used in the same chapter— But the close of the 21st. verse—the kingdom of God is within you, seems to have no connection whatever with the second advent of Christ— Mr Gurley gave notice that there would be no service at that church this afternoon; and I collected from his prayer, that the congregation have given a call to Dr. Ezra Stiles Ely, which he has accepted— After dinner at St. John’s church Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the fourth Sunday in Lent, and preached from Isaiah 30.26. [“]Moreover the light of the moon shall be as the light of the sun, and the light of the sun shall be sevenfold, as the light of seven days, in the day that the Lord bindeth up the breach of his people, and healeth the stroke of their wound” It is not always easy to discern the connection between Mr Hawley’s text and his discourse, nor especially his propensity to select his texts from the Book of Isaiah— This Chapter itself and the text as a part of it is abundantly obscure— It begins with imprecations against the people of Judah who relied upon the aid of the Egyptians, to protect them from being conquered and oppressed by the Assyrians; and finished by a dark prediction of redemption from the Assyrian yoke— And a declaration that Tophet is ordained of old—for the king—deep and large—the pile, fire and much wood—and the breath of the Lord like a stream of brimstone kindles it— This is generally understood to be the Bible description of Hell; but who can form a distinct conception of what it is.— Certainly not the place nor the condition adverted to in Mr Hawley’s text— My time was much absorbed in recording the double diary of yesterday, much of my conversation with D. Webster being omitted.

The Revd. Mr Weems called on me again this morning to request of me a certificate of facts relating to a controversy between him and William A. Weaver, who was the superintendent clerk at the Department of State for printing the census. Weaver, under cover of this appointment to superintend the printing of the census had undertaken a private job to prepare a compendium or abridgment of it for which he had contracted with Blair and Rives that they should pay him 3500 dollars. On the 9th. of June 1841. The House of Representatives at my motion passed a Resolution calling on the President for a return of the aggregates by Counties and Cities— I called at the Department of State, where Weavers work as far as it was finished was shewn to me by Mr Webster’s order, and I said that was what I wanted and I was told it was nearly finished— But no answer to the Resolution was returned by the President, at that Session, nor until the 4th. of January 1842. when a Report from the Secretary of State, with a totally different document was sent to the House— Weems had told me that Weaver was secretly bargaining with Blair and Rives to give the printing of the document unlawfully to Blair and Rives, and wished me to insist with the Secretary of State that the printing should be done by Gales and Seaton the Printers of the house; but not chusing to meddle with that question I declined speaking to Mr Webster about it— Weaver succeeded in his bargain of plunder with Blair and Rives— Thomas Allen the Printer of the Senate screwed out of Webster another bargain for printing the same document—and counter memorials and a select Committee of investigation, and scurrilous counter pamphlets will, terminate by payment of all the printers bills, and the complete fleecing of the public— Weems says that Weaver has falsified the printing of his testimony before the investigating committee and then presented his own falsification as evidence to support a charge against Weems of perjury before the grand jury.— He asked me again for a certificate, which I promised to write, and to have ready for him to-morrow— I called at the Department of State, and returned to Mr Webster his Letter of Instructions to Edward Everett—the Instructions of Secretary Upshur to Commodore Mattew C.
