Perry, and the Office copy of Mr Guizot’s Letter to General Cass in answer to his Protest— A very short further conversation with Mr Webster— He wishes another Negotiation with Great-Britain— But they keep Mr Fox here; only to make him pensionable— He has a private Letter from Everett, and one from Lord Ashburton— They will take the line of the Columbia river, and let us stretch South at the expence of Mexico— Mr Fox came in and I went into Mr Hunter’s chamber, where he brought several of the Archives of the Departme and among the rest the correspondence of Anthony Butler. His Letter to Forsyth of 17. June 1835 must be read again.

Mr Connell called on me this morning and requested of me a Letter of introduction to Mr Pageot the Chargé d’Affaires from France— His purpose is to request Mr Pageot to forward for him a Memorial to Louis Philippe the king of the French, setting forth certain services of relief, kindness and humanity which in the year 1813 to numerous French Officers returning from the wreck of Napoleon’s army which invaded Russia.— He had a volume of Niles Register published in 1820. containing a narrative of these transactions and bearing the most authentic and unqualified testimony to Mr Connell’s services at that time, at considerable inconvenience and expence to himself— He said that he had recently met with so many misfortunes in his private concerns that he was reduced to great distress, and had been advised by some of his friends, particularly by Mr John Spear Smith, to address this memorial to the king of France, who upon this state of facts would feel himself under obligations to remunerate those services.— I told him that I would very cheerfully give him a Letter to Mr Pageot; but that I could scarcely say I was acquainted with him— There was no personal intercourse between him and me, and had been none between his predecessor Bacourt and me, since I questioned in a public Lecture, Louis Philippe’s title to the crown— This fact I knew had been reported to the king, and therefore a Letter of recommendation from me would do him harm rather than good— Connell did not seem to be satisfied, but did not insist— My morning wasted away till it was near 2. O’Clock P.M before I reached the Department, and immediately went into Hunter’s chamber. I made an abstract of the Letter from William A. Slacum a purser in the Navy, (since deceased,) to the Secretary of State Forsyth, dated Alexandria 1. August 1835.— This was the Letter which kindled the passion of Andrew Jackson for the 37th. line of Latitude from the river Arkansas to the South Sea—to include the river and Bay of San Francisco—and was the foundation of Forsyth’s instruction to Butler of 6. Augt. 1835. authorizing him to offer 500000 dollars more, than he had received authority to offer before.— There is another long Letter from Slacum, relating to the commerce of the several South American States— Both prove him to have been an observing man— I had not time to begin the abstract of Butler’s Letter to Forsyth of 17 June 1835— The substance of which is a proposal to purchase the cession of Texas by bribing a priest named Ygnacio Hernandez with 500000 dollars, and he encloses a note signed Hernandez assuring him that with 500000 (he says not what) he will certainly obtain his object— There is an endorsement on this Letter signed A. J. forbidding bribery or corruption— Walter Hellen was here this afternoon, and we had as evening visitors Mr King the Painter, Greenough the Sculptor, and John Connell.

The months of January and March for the present year 1843. changed places in the atmosphere, the first having been so springlike, that the buds on the fruit trees were bursting into blossom, and I remember no month of January at Washington so frost benumbed and snow clad as has been this expiring month of March— This day however it relented, and seems preparing according to its proverbial character to go out like a lamb. My cough is apparently subsiding, but my plan of occupation is broken up, and I am irretrievably spellbound in idleness— The day was fair and the temperature mild; but my vis inertiae so insuperable that it was near one when I got to Mr Hunter’s chamber at the Department of State— I took up again the Volume of Anthony Butler’s despatches to the Department of State and to President Jackson during his mission to Mexico, and began the abstract of his Letter to Forsyth of 17. June 1835.— But I made little progress, my attention being diverted from that Letter to other parts of the correspondence, and to the reading of numerous other Letters— I found that I could not understand the subject thoroughly but by a rigorous chronological examination of all the documents— The appetite for Texas was from the first a Western passion, stimulated by no one more greedily than by Henry Clay.— He had denounced the Florida Treaty for fixing the boundary at the Sabine; and held and preached the doctrine that we should have insisted upon our shadow of a claim to the Rio del Norte— President Monroe actually preferred the line of the Sabine, thinking that the extension of the boundary woaken us for defence— And Jackson expressly approved the line of the Sabine— The first act of the Mexican Government after declaring their Independence was to claim the boundary as settled by the Florida Treaty and we had consented to it. But with the commencement of my administration I appointed Poinsett Minister to Mexico and Mr Clay instructed him to propose the purchase of Texas— This they declined but two years after the proposition was renewed— They then rejected it resentfully.— But Jackson was so sharp set for Texas, that from the first year of his administration, he set his double engines to work of negotiating to buy Texas with one hand and instigating the people of that province to revolt against Mexico with the other Houston was his Agent for the rebellion, and Anthony Butler, a Mississippi Land-jobber in Texas, for the purchase— Butler kept him five years on the tenter hooks of expectation—negotiating, wheedling, promising and finally boasting that he had secured the bargain by bribing a priest with half a million of dollars— Jackson at last found him out and dismissed him rather abruptly. But he carried off some of the most important documents of the negotiation— They exchanged the ratifications of a new convention this day at the Department of State. D. L. Child spent the Evening here—

The change of the Season has been this day completed, by the substitution rather of Summer than of Spring, for the Winter which has ruled supreme over the month of March— My cough has very much subsided but has left in its place a listless languid incapacity of action, which operates upon me as a palsy, and baffles all my good purposes—

lg.l: “For we are old, and on our quick’st decrees
The inaudible and noiseless foot of time
Steals, ere we can effect them.”

div.p: I walked this morning to the Capitol, and on my way met Joseph L. Williams, a member of the last Congress from Tennessee, who is yet here. He told me that Henry A. Wise, who has offered himself as a Candidate for re-election to Congress, in a stump speech at Louisa last week qualified Henry Clay as a sot and a liar.

At the capitol I obtained two copies of the Message of the President of 18. Feby last, relating to the seizure by Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones of the Mexican town of Monterey in California; and several other Documents concerning Mexico and Texas of which I had made a list, In the Resolution of the house, calling for the Monterey document, I had called for all the Instructions to Commodore Jones, and all his communications to the Navy Department—purposely omitting the usual exception of such as the President might deem it improper to communicate— I had moved the Resolutions by direction of the Committee of foreign affairs though it is not so stated on the journal of the house— Cushing voted against the Resolutions in Committee and was at his request excused from voting on them in the house because they did not contain the exception. The Message adverting to the omission of the exception, assumes a discretionary power in the executive to with hold any documents called for by Resolution of the house, but says that in this case all are given because he sees no necessity for withholding any.— I believe that at the next Session of Congress, it will be my duty to move some action of Congress on this document, though I have no hope of succeeding in that or in any thing else— Never in my life was there such an array of discouragement before— Never despair!— Returning from the capitol I stop’d at the National Intelligencer Office and obtained from W. W. Seaton the four papers containing the correspondence relating to Cass’s protest against the ratification of the Quintuple Treaty; and the subsequent controversy between Cass and Webster about the Ashburton Treaty— After my return home, a dull headache, and overpowering lassitude disabled me for the rest of the day, till late in the evening when I made out to finish a statement for Jesse E. Weems, about my call for the aggregates of the census returns, and the rascally job, perpetrated between William A. Weaver and Blair and Rives for the printing of the compendium.— I received a Letter from Mr Frye, with a note from the Miller Speakman, informing me that the snow and rainstorm of Tuesday Night carried away the milldam, and that of course the rent from that day ceases— My wife received also a Letter from our Son dated that same Tuesday Evening at Stonington where he had been with his wife since the Evening before, detained by the storm— She was coming here—but from fear of embarking on the Sound, they concluded to return the next morning to Boston.

A person by the name of Russell, an inventor of some astronomical instrument came and requested of me a certificate of its usefulness. He had some time last year brought it to my house and exhibited it to me, but I did not understand its mechanism or its operation sufficiently to judge of its usefulness— I declined giving him a certificate upon my general rule— He had one from the Revd. Dr Ezra Stiles Ely.— Mr Child was here this morning; and I gave him a copy of the reprinted Executive Documents N. 40 and 42 of the 1st. Session of the 25th. congress 1837. containing the most important papers of our relations with Mexico and Texas. I desired him to ascertain from Genl Almonte whether the paper delivered by Anthony Butler to Lucas Alaman, on the 15th. of July 1832, and another paper afterwards delivered by Butler to Santa Anna, and never answered by him are not among the Archives of the Mexican Government, and if they are to obtain copies of them— I requested him also to endeavour to procure the St. Louis Newspapers containing Benton’s Essays under the signatures of Americanus and La Salle in 1829. which he promised to do. I called to see Mr T. B. Johnson, who is afflicted with a paralytic disease; the issue of which may occur from hour to hour, and yet may linger along for years— Thence I went to the Department of State, and put into the hands of Mr Webster the last Letter received from Dr Flügel of 25. November last, imploring my aid to obtain an allowance of his charges in an account for expences not authorised by Law, but which he was ill able to bear, and had incurred without knowing that they were not allowable.— I told him that Dr Flügel was an entire Stranger to me, but that Mr Wheaton had recommended him to me, as a very poor but respectable man of Letters— Mr Webster took the papers and said he would see what he could do for the Doctor— He sent me also the London Globe and Times Newspapers received down to the 3d. of this Month— We said something about the North eastern boundary maps, and I mentioned one to him as being in the Department which he had not seen. I then passed into Hunter’s chamber, and made a short further abstract from Anthony Butler’s Letter to John Forsyth of 17. June 1835— Hunter had the first number of a Texan Newspaper Feby last. containing a list of the members of the Executive Government— Also a list of the Masonic Government— A Royal Arch Chapter, of which Anthony Butler is the Grand High Priest. Without finishing my abstract, I came home at 4 O’Clock in the Rain which continued steadily all the afternoon and evening. Joseph H. Adams was here, and also Miss Cutts— This afternoon Mr Richard I. Morsell came and made his annual payment of 300 dollars for the purchase of the house and lot in square 214— In the Evening Isaac Hull and Mary and her daughter read for me in the London Globe of 1. March a curious debate in the house of Commons on the subject of education.
